for.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: used to say who is intended to get or use something, or where something is intended to be used
for.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: I’ve got a present for you.
Someone left a message for Vicky.
an English course for foreign students
We need a new battery for the radio.
These chairs are for the office.
for.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: in order to help someone or something
for.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: I looked after the kids for them.
Let me carry that bag for you.
The doctor knew that there was nothing he could do for her.
Charles died fighting for his country.
What can I do for you  (=used to ask a customer if you can help them)?
for.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: used to say what the purpose of an object, action etc is
for.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: What did you do that for?
I’ve bought him a watch for his birthday.
the documents prepared for his defence
for.translation[0].definitions[2].note_b: You say that something is for doing a particular thing
This is for pulling up weeds
This is for to pull up weeds
You say that someone does something in order to do a particular thing
They borrowed money in order to build up the business
They needed money for to build up the business
You say that someone does something to do a particular thing
She went downtown to do some shopping
She went downtown for to do some shopping
for.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: in order to have, do, get, or obtain something
for.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Are you waiting for the bus?
the qualifications necessary for a career in broadcasting
Mother was too ill to get up for dinner.
For further details, write to this address.
for.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: used to say how long an action or situation continues for
for.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: We had been talking for a good half hour.
He’s been off work for a while.
for.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: Factories stretch for quite a way along the canal.
for.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: if something is arranged for a particular time, it is planned that it should happen then
for.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: A meeting was arranged for 18th May.
for.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: used to say where a person, vehicle etc is going
for.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: A few days later she would be leaving for New York.
for.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: used to say what the price or value of something is
for.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: a cheque for a hundred pounds
The diamond was insured for two thousand dollars.
for.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: because of or as a result of something
for.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: If, for any reason, you cannot attend, please inform us.
We could hardly see for the mist.
You’ll feel better for a break.
a reward for making good progress
Campbell was arrested for dangerous driving.
for.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: used to say which thing or person your statement or question is related to
for.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: I’m sure she’s the ideal person for the job.
The questions on this paper are too difficult for 10-year-olds.
Are you all right for money?
Fortunately for him, he can swim.
for.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: used to say which person or thing your feelings are directed towards
for.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: I came away feeling sorry for poor old George.
My deep love for him still remains.
They show no respect for authority.
for.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: used to say at which meal you eat something
for.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: used to say which company, team etc you belong to
for.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: I’ve worked for the BBC ever since I left university.
Deborah used to play for the A team.
He writes for a weekly paper.
for.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: supporting or in agreement with something or someone
for.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: We have studied the arguments for and against nuclear energy.
How many people voted for the proposal?
I’m all for giving people more freedom.
for.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: used to say what a word or sign means
for.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: used to say that a particular quality of someone or something is surprising when you consider what they are
for.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: She looks young for her age.
for.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: as a representative of other people
for.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: Paisley claims to speak for the majority of local people.
for.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: used to say what is possible, difficult, necessary, unusual etc
for.translation[0].definitions[18].examp: It’s unusual for Donald to be so bad-tempered.
There is an urgent need for someone to tackle this problem.
Here is a chance for everyone to learn new skills.
There’s nothing worse than for a parent to ill-treat a child.
It was too far for her to walk in high-heeled shoes.
for.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: used to introduce the reason for something
for.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: I cannot tell whether she is old or young, for I have never seen her.
He found it increasingly difficult to read, for his eyesight was beginning to fail.
